content.text: The student forgets to reset the stopwatch at the start of the race. Fig. 1.1 shows the time on the stopwatch at the start and the time after going around the track once
Calculate the time the car takes to go around the track once, in seconds
The length of the track is \(4.0\mathrm{km}\) . The car goes around the track 20 times. The car takes 26 minutes and 40 seconds to complete the 20 laps
Calculate the average speed of the car in m/s
average speed = .........m/s
State the section of the graph that shows the greatest acceleration
Explain your answer
Calculate the distance travelled by the car during the first 2.5 seconds
distance = .........m
[Total: 11]
Fig. 1.2 shows a speed-time graph for the car during part of the race
A student watches a car race around a track. He uses a stopwatch to measure the time for the car to make one lap of the track
Calculate the weight of one \(50\mathrm{g}\) mass
The student uses the \(50\mathrm{g}\) masses as loads to stretch a spring
Fig. 2.1 shows the apparatus the student uses to obtain readings for a load-extension graph
Describe how the student could use the apparatus and ensure that the readings are accurate
[Total: 7]
A student is using some \(50\mathrm{g}\) masses
Calculate the density of the steel ball
density = .........$g / cm^3$
The ball falls to the ground from rest. At a time of 0.2 s after it started to fall, its acceleration is \(10 \text{m/s}^2\)
State the acceleration of the ball at a time of 0.1 s after it started to fall
The mass of a small steel ball is \(120 \text{g}\). The volume of the ball is \(16.0 \text{cm}^3\)
State the name given to each of the forces shown in Fig. 3.1
Calculate the size of the resultant force on the ball
resultant force = .........N
[Total: 6]
Fig. 3.1 shows the vertical forces that act on a large plastic ball as it is falling
Fig. 3.1 (not to scale)
A lamp is attached to a wall, as shown in Fig. 4.1
Calculate the moment of the lamp about the pivot. Give the unit
[Total: 4]
Fig. 5.1 shows a metal can containing air. The can is sealed with a lid
The air in the can exerts a pressure of \(20 000 \text{N} / \text{m}^2\) on the lid. The area of the can lid is \(0.09 \text{m}^2\)
Calculate the force on the lid due to the air in the can
The air in the can becomes warmer
State and explain what happens to the pressure of the air in the can. Use your ideas about gas molecules
[Total: 6]
in the first five minutes
in the last five minutes
For can X, use Fig. 6.2 to determine the drop in temperature of the water
Explain why the water cools at a greater rate during the first five minutes of the experiment, compared with the last five minutes
The outside of one can is dull black and the outside of the other is shiny white
State the colour of can Y
Explain your answer
[Total: 6]
A student investigates the thermal energy lost from two metal cans, X and Y. The cans are identical apart from their outside colour
The student pours the same volume of hot water into each can and seals each can. The student records the temperature of the water in each can at regular time intervals for a period of 35 minutes
The equipment is shown in Fig. 6.1
Fig. 6.2 is a graph of the results from the investigation
In Fig. 7.1, section **A** and section **B** of the electromagnetic spectrum are not labelled
State the names of these parts
A
B
An electromagnetic wave has a wavelength of \(1.0 \times 10^{-9} \text{m}\). Use Fig. 7.1 to identify the type of electromagnetic wave
All electromagnetic waves travel at the same speed in a vacuum
State one other property that is the same for all electromagnetic waves
remote controllers for televisions
killing bacterial cells
For each purpose, state one type of electromagnetic radiation that can be used
Fig. 7.1 shows an incomplete diagram of the electromagnetic spectrum
wavelength/m
A loud sound has a large
A student listens to two sounds. The sound with the higher frequency has a higher
The boxes contain words about waves
Complete each sentence. Choose a term from each box
Explain what is meant by the term ultrasound
Describe a method that the student could use. You may draw a diagram to help you
[Total: 5]
A student magnetises a steel rod by using a permanent magnet
State the name for the component labelled X and state its function in this circuit
name for component
function
Describe how the circuit shown in Fig. 10.1 could be used to find the resistance of the fixed resistor R
Fig. 10.1 shows an electrical circuit
Calculate the current in the heater
current = .........A
Suggest a rating for the fuse to be fitted to the mains plug for the heater
fuse rating = .........A
An electrical heater has a resistance of \(21.8 \Omega\) when connected to a \(240 \text{V}\) mains supply
On Fig. 11.1, draw the pattern of the magnetic field lines around the coil
Add arrows to show the direction of the magnetic field
A long soft iron bar is placed inside the plastic tube. There is a current in the coil. This forms a device. State the name of the device
Fig. 11.2 shows a relay operated by switch S
Using Fig. 11.2, describe how closing the switch, S, causes the electric motor to operate
[Total: 8]
Fig. 11.1 shows a coil (solenoid) wrapped around a plastic tube. There is a current in the coil. The arrows show the direction of the current in the coil
Fig. 12.1 shows a diagram to represent a helium atom, and an incomplete key
Complete the key in Fig. 12.1. State the name of each particle
The table in Fig. 12.2 compares two isotopes of helium
For each isotope, write the number of protons and the number of neutrons in the correct places in the table
Describe the penetrating ability of \(\alpha\) -particles
Explain why it is dangerous to swallow a source that emits \(\alpha\) -particles
[Total: 7]
The nucleus of the helium atom in (a) is the same as an \(\alpha\) -particle
